quiz.title: Unit 4: Elasticity (Quiz 6)
quiz.subtitle: 4.6 Cross Price Elasticity of Demand: Substitute and Complement Relationships (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Cross Price Elasticity, Substitute Goods, Complementary Goods

questions.question: Cross price elasticity of demand (XED) measures:
options: How quantity demanded responds to price changes of the same good
How quantity demanded responds to price changes of a related good
How quantity demanded responds to income changes
How supply responds to price changes
questions.explanation: Cross price elasticity measures the percentage change in quantity demanded of one good divided by the percentage change in price of another related good.

questions.question: The formula for cross price elasticity of demand is:
options: % change in quantity of good A / % change in price of good A
% change in quantity of good A / % change in price of good B
% change in price of good A / % change in quantity of good B
% change in quantity of good A / % change in income
questions.explanation: XED = (% change in quantity demanded of good A) / (% change in price of good B)

questions.question: If XED is positive, the two goods are:
questions.explanation: Positive XED indicates substitute goods - when the price of one increases, demand for the other increases as consumers switch to the alternative.

questions.question: If XED is negative, the two goods are:
questions.explanation: Negative XED indicates complementary goods - when the price of one increases, demand for both decreases because they are consumed together.

questions.question: If the price of coffee increases by 10% and demand for tea increases by 15%, the XED between tea and coffee is:
questions.explanation: XED = (% change in quantity of tea) / (% change in price of coffee) = 15% / 10% = 1.5. Positive value confirms they are substitutes.

questions.question: If XED = 0, the two goods are:
questions.explanation: Zero XED indicates unrelated goods - changes in the price of one good have no effect on demand for the other.

questions.question: Which pair of goods would likely have the highest positive cross price elasticity?
questions.explanation: Butter and margarine are close substitutes with high positive XED - consumers easily switch between them when prices change.

questions.question: If the price of smartphones increases by 20% and demand for smartphone cases decreases by 10%, the XED is:
questions.explanation: XED = (% change in quantity of cases) / (% change in price of phones) = -10% / 20% = -0.5. Negative value confirms they are complements.

questions.question: The magnitude of XED indicates:
options: How strongly the goods are related as substitutes or complements
The price level of the goods
questions.explanation: The absolute value of XED shows the strength of the relationship - higher values indicate stronger substitute or complement relationships.

questions.question: Which pair would have negative cross price elasticity?
options: Hot dogs and hot dog buns
questions.explanation: Hot dogs and hot dog buns are complements - when the price of one increases, demand for both decreases because they are consumed together.

questions.question: If XED between two goods is +0.8, they are:
questions.explanation: Positive XED of 0.8 indicates substitute goods, but the relatively low value suggests they are weak substitutes rather than perfect substitutes.

questions.question: Businesses use cross price elasticity information to:
options: Understand competitive relationships and pricing strategies
questions.explanation: Understanding XED helps businesses identify competitors, anticipate market reactions to price changes, and develop effective pricing strategies.

questions.question: If the price of movie tickets decreases by 15% and demand for popcorn increases by 9%, the XED is:
questions.explanation: XED = (% change in quantity of popcorn) / (% change in price of tickets) = 9% / (-15%) = -0.6. Negative value confirms they are complements.

questions.question: Perfect substitutes would have XED approaching:
questions.explanation: Perfect substitutes have very high positive XED - consumers completely switch from one to the other when relative prices change.

questions.question: For complementary goods, if the price of good A increases, demand for good B:
questions.explanation: For complements, price increase in one good reduces demand for both goods because they are consumed together.

questions.question: The cross price elasticity between different brands of the same product is typically:
questions.explanation: Different brands of the same product are close substitutes, so they have strongly positive cross price elasticity.

questions.question: If XED between two goods is -2.5, they are:
questions.explanation: Negative XED of -2.5 indicates strong complements - the goods are highly dependent on each other in consumption.

questions.question: When analyzing market competition, businesses look for products with:
options: High positive XED with their product
High negative XED with their product
questions.explanation: High positive XED identifies close competitors - products that consumers view as substitutes for the business's product.

questions.question: If the price of electric cars decreases and demand for gasoline decreases, the XED between gasoline and electric cars is:
questions.explanation: Electric cars and gasoline cars are substitutes. When electric car prices fall, consumers switch from gasoline cars, reducing gasoline demand - positive XED.

questions.question: The main value of cross price elasticity analysis is that it:
options: Shows how goods are interrelated in consumer decision-making
questions.explanation: XED reveals how products are connected in consumers' minds - whether they view them as substitutes, complements, or unrelated - which is crucial for strategic planning.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand cross price elasticity and can identify substitute and complement relationships between products.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basic concepts but review how to calculate XED and interpret the magnitude of the values.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: Positive XED = substitutes; Negative XED = complements; Higher absolute values = stronger relationships.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that cross price elasticity shows how demand for one good responds to price changes of another good, revealing substitute or complement relationships.
